dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eva, 45 and attractive, gets out of her old Prius, takes a large massage table and proceeds to carry it to the apartment building. She’s wearing sweatpants and sneakers ready for work.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A middle aged man, MARTIN, is enjoying his massage. Face gaping mouth and utterly relaxed, Eva works on his neck a shoulders from behind him.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: Oh, yeah, right there, my neck. Perfect.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: Take a deep breath and hold it a minute. (he does) Now, exhale. He lets out a long exhale and Eva almost falls over from BAD BREATH. She has to back up.

dialogues.speaker: EVA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Good...

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: Should I do it again?

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: No, no. One is good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eva gives a massage to CYNTHIA, 35, who lies face down. Despite the soothing music, Cynthia talks loudly and constantly.

dialogues.speaker: CYNTHIA
dialogues.text: She brought cupcakes, I brought cake pops, and she goes “they’re the same thing” but they’re not the same thing because a cupcake is a cupcake, a cake pop is a cake with a stick in it. Anyway, the real issue is her daughter because she’s not very smart whereas my daughter Anna...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: cynthia rolls over, continuing to talk. When she’s on her back Eva closes Cynthia's eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eva lugs her large massage table up the stairs to an apartment. It’s heavy and clumsy. The front door (at the of the stairs) opens up and HAL, 30, greets her.

dialogues.speaker: HAL
dialogues.text: Hey Eva. Come on up! He smiles and watches her struggle up the stairs, not helping.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A cute, well kept bungalow type place.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eva is at her mirror putting on lipstick. Her daughter EL 18 and cute, comes in returning a necklace to the dresser

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN
dialogues.text: Hey mom. Where are you going?

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: To a party with Sarah and Will so they don't have to be alone. (beat) You want to come?

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: Because you’re leaving soon and we should hang out.

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN
dialogues.text: I’m good. She heads back into her own room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will (42) drives. His wife Sarah (40) sits beside him put on some makeup. Eva listens from the backseat as they exp something to her.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: We can never find anything.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: She puts things in the weirdest places. Like, if I leave my bracelets on the kitchen counter she’ll put them in a drawer in the kitchen. (to Will) Why can’t you just do it?

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: I always do it. I fired the gardener. It's not fair.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: (to Eva) We want to fire her but he won’t do it. (to Will) It’s not hard for you. Why does it have to be fair?

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: You should do it because it’s hard for you.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: oh, please.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: Come on Sarah, grow up. You can fire a maid.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: Is that the definition of maturity? Being able to fire your friggin’ maid?

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: (leaning forward, showing her lipstick) Sarah, does this color look good on me?

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: You look good. Pretty.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: That's nice. Nice look.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will, Sarah and Eva scan the large party and the beautifu back yard.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: So whose party is this?

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: Well, he’s a big book agent and she’s an interior designer. They know everyone.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: Maybe there’s single men here. Oh shit, I see a patient.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: What are you going to do?

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: I don’t know. Ignore her until I can’t.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: Show me. Introduce me!

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: No way.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: You're a wet blanket. Oh, I see someone from my gym. Eva wanders off to say Hi to the gym woman, HILARY. She's standing with another very attractive and stylish woman, MARIANNE. Both are mid 40's.

dialogues.speaker: HILARY
dialogues.text: Eva - hi. This is Marianne. This is Eva. Eva's a fabulous masseuse.

dialogues.speaker: MARIANNE
dialogues.text: Oh! Nice to meet you.

dialogues.speaker: HILARY
dialogues.text: Oh, will you guys excuse me for a sec? I've got to find a bathroom. She walks off leaving Marianne and Eva alone.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: That was abrupt.

dialogues.speaker: EVA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Wow, I love what you’re wearing. Your dress, and your shoes and your purse.

dialogues.speaker: MARIANNE
dialogues.text: Oh, thanks. Gee, I should bring you everywhere. I love your outfit. So, you're a masseuse. And you're good?

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: I am.

dialogues.speaker: EVA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What is it that you do?

dialogues.speaker: MARIANNE
dialogues.text: I'm a poet.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: And I’m a dreamer.

dialogues.speaker: MARIANNE
dialogues.text: No. Really.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: Oh. You - you're really a poet?

dialogues.speaker: MARIANNE
dialogues.text: I am.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: And you make a living?

dialogues.speaker: MARIANNE
dialogues.text: I do!

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: You're a poet. Now I know it.

dialogues.speaker: MARIANNE
dialogues.text: Good one.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: Feel free to steal it!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will standing alone, drinking. Eva walks up.

dialogues.speaker: EVA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I think I just got a new client.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: Where? Eva points. They see Marianne being fawned over by a COUP OF GUESTS. WILL (CONT’D) She looks clean.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: She’s really nice. And funny. Great taste.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: And extremely attractive.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: You think every woman at this party is attractive.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: Pretty much. Eva looks around.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: There is not one man here that I’m attracted to. Just then TWO MEN approach Will. One is JASON, 50.

dialogues.speaker: JASON
dialogues.text: Will, didn’t know you'd be here!

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: Hey Jason. This is my friend Eva.

dialogues.speaker: JASON
dialogues.text: Hi. This is Albert. They all shake hands. ALBERT is 45 and has a bit of a bel

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: Nice party, huh? Lots of white balls hanging down.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: Eva was just telling me that there’s not one man at this party that she’s attracted to.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: Okay! I don’t know why you would make that announcement?

dialogues.speaker: ALBERT
dialogues.text: Is that unusual?

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: No, not unusual at all. And no offense.

dialogues.speaker: ALBERT
dialogues.text: (Joking) That's okay, I’m not attracted to anyone here, either.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: Okay. Good. Yeah, it’s kind of an ugly crowd.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: (making conversation) Jason, you've got a kid in college now, right?

dialogues.speaker: JASON
dialogues.text: Two.

dialogues.speaker: ALBERT
dialogues.text: I've got one leaving in the fall.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: So do I.

dialogues.speaker: ALBERT
dialogues.text: It’s all I have.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: Me too!

dialogues.speaker: JASON
dialogues.text: Oh come on, you guys. You want your kids to go away! It’s healthy!

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: Shut up.

dialogues.speaker: ALBERT
dialogues.text: Yeah, shut up. Albert looks at Eva, clearly charmed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sarah and Will drive home from the party, Eva is in the backseat.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: Do all the guys get boners?

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: Haven't we been over this?

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: Massages make me nervous. I spend the whole time afraid I’m gonna get a boner.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: You are?

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: So, do they hit on you?

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: You know you're starting to depress me. They don’t get boners and they don’t hit on me.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: So, who do you massage? It must be so strange.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: I've got a guy who’s got like a hundred stairs to his house and he never helps me with my massage table.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: Did you ever ask him to?

dialogues.speaker: EVA AND SARAH
dialogues.text: I/She shouldn't have to! She gets out of the car.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: Bye guys. Love you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eva gets out of the car, walks up to the house and opens front door. INT. ELLEN’S ROOM - NIGHT Ellen is asleep in her bed. Eva enters and stares at her child for a long, long time. It‘s unfathomable how much she loves this person.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eva's car pulls into the parking lot. Ellen and Chloe get and immediately they trot off with THREE FRIENDS.

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN
dialogues.text: Bye mom!

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: (out the window) Have a good day honey.

dialogues.speaker: CHLOE
dialogues.text: Bye Eva, thanks for the ride!

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: Oh, you're welcome Chloe. Eva sees TWO OTHER GIRLS, MADDY and SAGE, dressed way too sexy, drop trash on the ground.

dialogues.speaker: EVA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Hey. Maddy Price! You littered. Maddy turns and dead pans to Eva.

dialogues.speaker: MADDY
dialogues.text: (in English accent) Excuse me, what did you say?

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: Pick up your trash. You're not British. Maddy picks up her trash.

dialogues.speaker: MADDY
dialogues.text: What a bitch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Eva drives away - EXT. MARIANNE’S SANTA MONICA HOUSE - DAY Eva carries her massage table up to this beautiful Spanis house. It’s not big, but it’s special.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bringing the table into the house, Eva admires the beauti place. It’s eclectic, colorful, creative, personal, perfe Fresh flowers everywhere, amazing art. Marianne wears a casual but chic outfit.

dialogues.speaker: MARIANNE
dialogues.text: Come on in. Would you mind removing your shoes?

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: No problem.

dialogues.speaker: MARIANNE
dialogues.text: And your socks too?

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: Sure.

dialogues.speaker: MARIANNE
dialogues.text: Would you like some ice tea? Eva takes off her shoes and socks as Marianne slips into kitchen. She then appears with a glass of iced tea.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: Oh yeah, that sounds good. I’m so glad you called. So many people take my card just to be polite!

dialogues.speaker: MARIANNE
dialogues.text: Well, I’m not polite!

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: (looking around) Wow, this is soooo pretty! Can I live here? (sipping ice tea) And this tea is kind of fabulous!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eva is working on Marianne while she lies on her back. Soothing music plays.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eva is putting her table back together while Marianne wea casual clothes and sits on the couch. They’re mid conversation.

dialogues.speaker: MARIANNE
dialogues.text: I'm dating this guy and he has no sense of humor.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: Could be a deal breaker.

dialogues.speaker: MARIANNE
dialogues.text: Right? I don’t know what to do because he’s very sweet.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: Sweet can be good. Find someone else to tell you jokes.

dialogues.speaker: MARIANNE
dialogues.text: Are you married?

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: Divorced. For ten years.

dialogues.speaker: MARIANNE
dialogues.text: Are you guys still friends?

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: Not really. We share a daughter. Other than that it’s hard to believe I ever had a laugh with the guy, let alone create a child.

dialogues.speaker: MARIANNE
dialogues.text: I know what you mean about your ex. We have zero in common. I don’t know how I ever had a real conversation with him.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: Crazy, isn't it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: EXT. MARIANNE’S HOUSE - DAY Eva is putting her massage table in her car while Mariann clips herbs in her front yard.

dialogues.speaker: MARIANNE
dialogues.text: Ill call you really soon. This left shoulder is still so tight.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: You ought to ice it tonight. And drink lots of water. Stay hydrated.

dialogues.speaker: MARIANNE
dialogues.text: I will. Thank you again. I’m so glad I met you! Oh, want some chervil? I’m drowning in it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She hands her some herbs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eva sits in her kitchen eating lunch, VIDEO CHATTING WITH SARAH.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: What the Hell is chervil? She said she was drowning in it.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: An herb. (in American accent) An herb. How long have you known me?

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: I can’t understand a goddamned thing you ever say.

dialogues.speaker: EVA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: The furniture was gorgeous. I wanted everything in there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sarah sits at her desk (in her therapy office) VIDEO CHATTING.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: She has no cellulite.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: How can that be?

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: I don’t know! There’s nothing!

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: Anyway, Will said that some guy you met at the party wants your number! Jason’s friend I think. Eva smiles, in spite of herself.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: But we both admitted we weren’t attracted to each other. (beat) What should I do? He’s kind of fat.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: He is?

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: He's got this big belly.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: Oh, come on. You have nothing to lose.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: No, but he does. Ha Ha Ha. Sarah just stares at her. Suddenly Eva notices the little light on the wall go on behind Sarah.

dialogues.speaker: EVA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Your patient just arrived. (beat) What if you never went out there. Would they just - (motions to shoot herself)? Oh, was that inappropriate?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TWELVE PEOPLE wait for a table outside a nondescript, sto front restaurant. Loud music blasts out onto the street f inside. Albert and Eva stand in front with the others, ma conversation. Everyone around them is YOUNG.

dialogues.speaker: ALBERT
dialogues.text: I’m sorry about this. I swear I made a dinner reservation.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: Oh. That's okay. (beat) What about you? What do you do?

dialogues.speaker: ALBERT
dialogues.text: I work at The American Library of Cultural History.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: The what?

dialogues.speaker: ALBERT
dialogues.text: Exactly. It’s basically a television library.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: (concerned) You watch a lot of TV.

dialogues.speaker: ALBERT
dialogues.text: (smiles) No, no. Television history. What’s on now? I have no clue. I tried to watch a Housewives of Idiot Town and I wanted to jump off a building.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: I watched one of those shows with my daughter once and I couldn’t believe it. They had no brains. And they all had fake cheekbones. And fake boobs. (beat) You like fake boobs?

dialogues.speaker: ALBERT
dialogues.text: I like real boobs.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: I got real boobs.

dialogues.speaker: ALBERT
dialogues.text: (awkward pause) Well, that’s working out for us then.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They’re mid meal and haven‘t run out of things to say. Th have to shout to be heard.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: How long have you been divorced?

dialogues.speaker: ALBERT
dialogues.text: About four years.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: And was it mutual?

dialogues.speaker: ALBERT
dialogues.text: (embarrassed) Not really, no.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: Uh uh. (beat) And can I get her number?

dialogues.speaker: ALBERT
dialogues.text: Of course.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: Imagine the time it would save.

dialogues.speaker: ALBERT
dialogues.text: Sometimes I think we should all just wear signs around our necks. Get it all out there.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: What would yours say?

dialogues.speaker: ALBERT
dialogues.text: I don’t know. I’m a slob? I have ear hair?

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: You know there’s ways to get rid of ear hair.

dialogues.speaker: ALBERT
dialogues.text: Fully aware. Taken care of.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: A slob, huh?

dialogues.speaker: ALBERT
dialogues.text: Not the dirty, hoarder kind, just the normal kind.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: Does your daughter live with you?

dialogues.speaker: ALBERT
dialogues.text: Half the time.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: Does she mind your normal kind of mess?

dialogues.speaker: ALBERT
dialogues.text: I’m not that bad. But both she and her mother are very neat. They love that store - Christ - the empty box store?

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: The Container Store?

dialogues.speaker: ALBERT
dialogues.text: A whole store that sells crap to put your crap in so you can buy more crap.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: I love that store. I love crap!

dialogues.speaker: ALBERT
dialogues.text: So did my ex wife. And she put it in very flowery and overpriced boxes.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: They sell those in some manly designs, you know.

dialogues.speaker: ALBERT
dialogues.text: Manly designs?

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: Yeah, browns. Little cowboys.

dialogues.speaker: ALBERT
dialogues.text: Little cowboys? Well, if they did, my wife would have bought them for me because she tried very hard to domesticate me.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: Living with someone else is not easy. Peoples habits.

dialogues.speaker: ALBERT
dialogues.text: Listen to this - (beat) I don’t like onions in my guacamole, right? So I would take a chip and kind of swirl it around until the onions were all on one side and then I could eat it. It drove her bananas.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: Seems kind of harmless.

dialogues.speaker: ALBERT
dialogues.text: Completely. But by the end of our marriage it made her gag.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: Well, that’s not nice. He notices her hands.

dialogues.speaker: ALBERT
dialogues.text: You have - um ~ lovely hands.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: Oh. Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: ALBERT
dialogues.text: I would have thought - since you’re a masseuse that you would have big, manly hands but they’re actually very lovely.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: (awkward) You have nice hands too.

dialogues.speaker: ALBERT
dialogues.text: (embarrassed) Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: They‘re kind of like paddles. (beat) Did they just turn the music louder?

dialogues.speaker: ALBERT
dialogues.text: No, I think you just got older. Eva flags down a WAITER.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: Excuse me, could you turn the music down a little bit? I’m old.

dialogues.speaker: WAITER
dialogues.text: No, I’m sorry.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: Are you sorry that I’m old, or that you won’t turn the music down?

dialogues.speaker: WAITER
dialogues.text: We can’t change the volume. The waiter walks away.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: He's nice.

dialogues.speaker: ALBERT
dialogues.text: I find I don’t like younger people.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: (with her hand to her ear) Eh?

dialogues.speaker: ALBERT
dialogues.text: I'm sorry. I picked the wrong restaurant.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: Oh I’m having a great time. The food is delicious. I mean I can’t hear anything you're saying.

dialogues.speaker: ALBERT
dialogues.text: That’s probably why you are having a great time.

dialogues.speaker: INT. MENCHIES YOGURT PLACE
dialogues.text: Albert and Eva put toppings on their yogurts at the self serve bar. Albert lifts a spoonful of something red.

dialogues.speaker: ALBERT
dialogues.text: What is this, tomatoes?

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: That's watermelon! There’s some croutons next to it. He chuckles and dumps some candy in his bowl.

dialogues.speaker: EVA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Doesn’t that sort of defeat the purpose?

dialogues.speaker: ALBERT
dialogues.text: What, it’s non fat yogurt. You can put a little stuff on it... She watches him dump more crap on and she smiles, amused. He looks at a COUPLE OF WOMEN looking very serious as the stand there tasting flavors out of little cups.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: What? The people tasting?

dialogues.speaker: ALBERT
dialogues.text: You know, just put some in your bowl. You're not buying a house!

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: It's free.

dialogues.speaker: ALBERT
dialogues.text: Yes, it’s free. They're happy!

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: (laughing) They have to taste. There’s many variations. Cake Batter, Red Velvet. (reading a sign) I have no idea what that is. Albert pays for their cups and takes out a photo of his daughter.

dialogues.speaker: ALBERT
dialogues.text: This is my daughter. CLOSE UP ON A PHOTO OF A BEAUTIFUL 18 YEAR OLD GIRL.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: Yowee. She’s gorgeous.

dialogues.speaker: ALBERT
dialogues.text: Looks like her mom, thank god. Eva turns on her phone and shows him a picture of Ellen. ALBERT (CONT’D) She's beautiful. (beat) You got any money?  ENOUGH SAID zu Flustered, Eva goes for her wallet. ALBERT (CONT’D) Just kidding. She laughs, relieved, as Albert takes out a twenty. INT. ALBERT’S AUDI - NIGHT Albert pulls his car up to Eva‘s house.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: Well, I had a really nice time.

dialogues.speaker: ALBERT
dialogues.text: Me, too. Albert leans in for a kiss but Eva leans back.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: I’m not sure.

dialogues.speaker: ALBERT
dialogues.text: Got it.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: I mean, maybe.

dialogues.speaker: ALBERT
dialogues.text: I understand.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: It's just that I’m not sure.

dialogues.speaker: ALBERT
dialogues.text: (playful) It's okay. I’m not deaf. (beat) Maybe a little deaf. She offers a hand and they shake.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: I like your paddles. She moves to get out.

dialogues.speaker: ALBERT
dialogues.text: I like your ass. Flattered and embarrassed, Eva beams.  ENOUGH SAID a

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: Well, thank you. Albert can’t believe he just said that as she gets out of car, waving.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She drops her purse and flops down on the couch next to E and Chloe. They are in a discussion, flipping through magazines and eating snacks.

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN
dialogues.text: How was it?

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: Nice!

dialogues.speaker: CHLOE
dialogues.text: But what if he immediately hooks up with someone else? I/1l die.

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN
dialogues.text: So don't do it.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN
dialogues.text: Nothing.

dialogues.speaker: CHLOE
dialogues.text: I can't decide if I should sleep with Chris or not. We're going to separate colleges and I don’t want to do it if I'm gonna regret it later.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: You're a virgin, right?

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN
dialogues.text: Don’t answer that.

dialogues.speaker: CHLOE
dialogues.text: (at same time) Yes.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: You can’t live in fear of making a mistake. If you want to do it, you should do it.

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN
dialogues.text: Stay out of it.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: She asked me!

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN
dialogues.text: She did?

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: Didn’t you Chloe? Chloe shrugs, stuck in the middle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eva sits on a couch outside the dressing rooms, knitting blanket. The girls are in a dressing room together.

dialogues.speaker: CHLOE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: That looks so cute!

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: You think?

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: (shouting to them) Show me! Come out!

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: I don’t like it. I’m gonna try this one.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: Hey. I forgot to ask you. What happened to Maddy Price? She was such a bitch the other day.

dialogues.speaker: CHLOE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: She had a threesome with Sage Berger and Brendan Weiss and now she thinks she’s Taylor Momson.

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Chloe! Don’t tell my mom that!

dialogues.speaker: CHLOE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Your mom's cool.

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: No, she’s not.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: She can tell me stuff. You never do! (stunned) They had a threesome?

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Forget it mom!

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: What is happening? (beat) Have you guys done that?

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Mom? Shut up.

dialogues.speaker: CHLOE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: That's such a pretty color. You look good.

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Really? I think I like it.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: Show me! They still ignore Eva.

dialogues.speaker: EVA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Hello? I’m the one buying it. Ellen comes out and shows her.

dialogues.speaker: EVA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You look beautiful! Chloe comes out wearing a tight short thing. Then her PRE MOTHER DEBBIE comes out of her own dressing room some distance away, wearing the same thing.

dialogues.speaker: EVA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (surprised) Look at you guys.

dialogues.speaker: CHLOE
dialogues.text: No way.

dialogues.speaker: DEBBIE
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: CHLOE
dialogues.text: We‘re not buying the same dress, mom.

dialogues.speaker: DEBBIE
dialogues.text: I won't wear it at the same time as you.

dialogues.speaker: CHLOE
dialogues.text: Come on. You look stupid.

dialogues.speaker: DEBBIE
dialogues.text: I think I look good.

dialogues.speaker: CHLOE
dialogues.text: You're so lumpy. Debbie looks at Eva for support.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: If I could wear that dress I would.

dialogues.speaker: DEBBIE
dialogues.text: Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: CHLOE
dialogues.text: You would not. Mom you look crazy. Disgusted, Chloe heads back into the dressing room.

dialogues.speaker: DEBBIE
dialogues.text: You’re not the only attractive girl in our family, Chloe.

dialogues.speaker: CHLOE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Oh please! (beat) Why can’t you just dress like Ellen's mom? She looks normal! Debbie glances at Eva’s attire and rolls her eyes as she into the dressing room. Eva sits there in JEANS, SNEAKERS BAGGY SWEATER. Knitting. Oh well. EXT. MARIANNE’S PATIO - DAY Eva is setting up her massage stuff as Marianne lies on h back. She places a bolster under her knees.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: (beat) So, what happened with your not-funny guy?

dialogues.speaker: MARIANNE
dialogues.text: Over. It’s fine. What about you? Do you have a boyfriend?

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: I had a good first date over the weekend.

dialogues.speaker: MARIANNE,
dialogues.text: How nice. What’s he like?

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: (putting a pillow under Marianne’s neck) Funny, and very sweet. We never stopped talking. It felt like we were old friends already.

dialogues.speaker: MARIANNE
dialogues.text: In a good way? ‘Cause that can sort of kill the chemistry.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: No, it was good. Flirtatious. I wasn’t sure if I wanted to kiss him though, but I think I do. When I first met him he didn’t seem attractive to me. He’s not typically handsome. But now I think he’s kind of sexy. INT. EVA‘S CAR - DAY Eva looks at Albert’s house as she drives up and parks. EXT. ALBERT’S WESTWOOD HOUSE - DAY A 1930's somewhat neglected one story house. The lawn is and the paint is peeling. The curtains are drawn inside. Holding a bottle of cheap champagne, Eva exits her car an walks up to the house. After a beat, Albert comes to the wearing a sweatshirt and pajama bottoms.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: Oh my god, did I get the day wrong?

dialogues.speaker: ALBERT
dialogues.text: No. Why?

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: You're wearing pajamas.

dialogues.speaker: ALBERT
dialogues.text: I’m not.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: oh.

dialogues.speaker: ALBERT
dialogues.text: I just like to be comfortable. You know, it’s brunch, it’s Sunday.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: Oh, good! INT. ALBERT’S HOUSE - CONTINUOUS It’s dark everywhere, all of the windows are shaded with curtains or blinds. He takes the champagne.

dialogues.speaker: ALBERT
dialogues.text: Thank you for this. I’1l make mimosas. Despite the dark, cave-like quality, it’s nice. Newish furniture, lots of books, an enormous flat screen TV. The are PHOTOS of TESS everywhere. Eva picks up a Chanel purse sitting on the table.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: You carry a purse?

dialogues.speaker: ALBERT
dialogues.text: That's my daughter's. Outrageously expensive but it was her 18th birthday.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bagels and coffee are ready and waiting on the counter. Albert makes drinks.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: Bagels! I love bread! So, tell me about her - your daughter, I mean.

dialogues.speaker: ALBERT
dialogues.text: Well, she’s very sophisticated - as you can tell from the pocketbook.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's smart, lovely and funny ~ and she’s moving to New York. Very far away. Going to Parsons school of design. I’m very proud of her.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: I bet.

dialogues.speaker: ALBERT
dialogues.text: But part of me thinks I shouldn’t let her go. You know? She’s 18 and this is a great opportunity for her but what if something happens to her while she’s in New York. I’1l never be able to forgive myself.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: The whole going away to college thing. We send them off? We don’t know where they are all the time? And aside from that, what’s my life going to look like when she’s gone? Lonely and pointless! (beat) Do you know that she doesn’t even want her father or me to take her there? She wants to say good-bye at the airport. Here. Not even fly with her.

dialogues.speaker: ALBERT
dialogues.text: That’s horrible.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: Heartbreaking, that’s the word for it. I guess we better develop hobbies.

dialogues.speaker: ALBERT
dialogues.text: Yeah. I guess so.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: I suppose I already have one. I knit. I'll just knit for the rest of my life. That’s my plan. What about you?

dialogues.speaker: ALBERT
dialogues.text: That's funny, because I weave.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: (taken aback) Like baskets?

dialogues.speaker: ALBERT
dialogues.text: Yeah, I do it in the garage.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: Really?

dialogues.speaker: ALBERT
dialogues.text: (beat) No. She cracks up.

dialogues.speaker: ALBERT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What would make you think that I would weave?

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: I don’t know! I’m actually kind of glad you don't weave.

dialogues.speaker: ALBERT
dialogues.text: Me, too. Then she looks down at Albert’s crotch and quickly looks away. ALBERT (CONT‘D) You know, I try to picture her not being here. I don’t see her all the time anyway, but it will completely different.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: Look, I can see your penis.

dialogues.speaker: ALBERT
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: (looking away) I saw your penis. Your pajama thing is kind of open. Albert instantly drops his hand to cover himself. He’s mortified. After a minute, he jokes.

dialogues.speaker: ALBERT
dialogues.text: Whaddya think?

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: I think you’re very... healthy.

dialogues.speaker: ALBERT
dialogues.text: Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: Go change your pants, okay?

dialogues.speaker: ALBERT
dialogues.text: Be right back. EXT. ALBERT’S BACKYARD - A BIT LATER Albert (in jeans) and Eva are drinking champagne. Albert in an old chair and Eva is on the ground pulling up weeds

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: So, what happened? I don’t mean the details, just the general.

dialogues.speaker: ALBERT
dialogues.text: I don’t think she liked me very much. We never had sex - not my choice, she just had no interest in it whatsoever. I’m pretty sure she cheated on me. That was awful. So obviously she liked sex but just not with me. She thought my job was stupid. I didn’t understand her. We parented very differently. Fought about it, always. (beat) Why are you wrecking my back yard?

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: You have a lot of weeds.

dialogues.speaker: ALBERT
dialogues.text: I do? Where?

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: These are all weeds.

dialogues.speaker: ALBERT
dialogues.text: I thought all that was good. He gets down on the grass and helps her.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: (beat) We never had sex either ~ not his choice. We were pretty out of synch in that way. (beat) We were out of synch with Ellen too. A lot of fighting over how to parent. (looking over) That’s all good grass you’re pulling up.

dialogues.speaker: ALBERT
dialogues.text: I'll put it back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He tries to replant it. Eva kicks off her shoes and rubs of her blistered feet.

dialogues.speaker: ALBERT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (beat) Got some kind of blister thing going there?

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: I guess.

dialogues.speaker: ALBERT
dialogues.text: Yup.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: You're grossed out.

dialogues.speaker: ALBERT
dialogues.text: No, no.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: You are. You’re freaked by my feet.

dialogues.speaker: ALBERT
dialogues.text: I have a little problem with feet. I think it has to do with my mother.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: Oh, she had feet.

dialogues.speaker: ALBERT
dialogues.text: Let’s just say they were overly colorful, like a rainbow. Yellow, blue ~ veins and blisters... She stares at him, then moves to put her shoe back on.

dialogues.speaker: ALBERT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You don’t have to do that.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: I think I should. (beat) I've never even had a pedicure. I know everyone has but I just never saw the point, until this actual moment. Plus I’m really ticklish.

dialogues.speaker: ALBERT
dialogues.text: Want me to get you a band-aid?

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: Please. And maybe a bag for my foot.

dialogues.speaker: ALBERT
dialogues.text: Stop it.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: Make it two bags. Two bags for the old bag!

dialogues.speaker: ALBERT
dialogues.text: I knew I shouldn't have told you! He goes into the house and Eva examines her foot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eva is putting a couple of band aids on her foot. They’re conversation.

dialogues.speaker: ALBERT
dialogues.text: They’re naked, right?

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: ALBERT
dialogues.text: Are you ever attracted to them?

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: (here we go) No. Never.

dialogues.speaker: ALBERT
dialogues.text: Well, I’m sure they’re attracted to you.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: I don’t know. They’re getting massaged.

dialogues.speaker: ALBERT
dialogues.text: They must hit on you all the time.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: (lying) Sometimes. Yeah. (beat) I'll give you a massage sometime, if you like.

dialogues.speaker: ALBERT
dialogues.text: I would like that. I would definitely hit on you.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: I think that might be okay.

dialogues.speaker: ALBERT
dialogues.text: Really. (beat) Want to kiss? They look at one another for a bit.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: sure. And they do. INT. ALBERT’S BEDROOM - THAT DAY Eva and Albert lie under the covers, having just had sex. Albert's bedroom is very sparse and lacks night stands. A of his stuff - books, tissues, clock ~ lays on the floor beside the bed. Eva reaches down for a glass of water.

dialogues.speaker: ALBERT
dialogues.text: You didn’t actually open your eyes at any point, did you?

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: No, no worries. I figured if I kept my eyes closed you wouldn’t see me.

dialogues.speaker: ALBERT
dialogues.text: I saw you. He pulls her to him.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: I'm tired of being funny.

dialogues.speaker: ALBERT
dialogues.text: Me too. They lie there for a minute not talking.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: But you’re not funny. He smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sarah and Eva are pushing a heavy piece of furniture acro the room. They’re getting help from Sarah’s son BRANDON ( and her daughter GRACE, (6), as well.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: I’m so excited for you! He sounds great.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: He kind of is. (whispering) We had such good sex.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: How fun! I can’t even imagine. Sarah stands back and looks at the furniture’s new spot.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What do you think?

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: I liked it where it was. You’re going to get a hernia.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: (to her kids) You guys can be done. Brandon and Grace walk into the other room.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: No Cleveland Show.

dialogues.speaker: BRANDON
dialogues.text: (without turning around) Please.

dialogues.speaker: GRACE
dialogues.text: Please.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: Okay.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: Jeez, you really put your foot down.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: Too tired to be a good parent.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: Maybe stop moving furniture around.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sarah flops down on the couch, picking up a decorating magazine. Sarah's maid CATHY, 30 and Hispanic, walks by straighteni up.

dialogues.speaker: EVA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What’s she doing here?

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: (talking quietly) You have no idea. Will refused to fire her so I let it go for a while hoping she’d just get better, but she got worse. She even seemed like she wanted to be fired cuz she was doing such stupid things.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: Well, good.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: So I fired her and she started crying. And then I started crying and then we were hugging and then I hired her back.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: You're nice.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: Right? Some people might think that I’m compassionate or soft hearted or whatever, but Will just thinks I’m a baby. He wants me to fire her again as a learning experience.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: Jesus.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: That’s our relationship, right there.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: Oh come on, it’s so much more than that.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: Whatever. He’s an jerk. He was a middle child and never got enough fried chicken at the dinner table and thinks everything has to be fair. Cathy appears.

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: Mrs. Sarah. Where do you want me to put this? It was in the bathroom. She holds up a ping pong paddle.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: Outside? With the ping pong table.

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: Okay, no problem. She goes off and the two share a smile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Albert's car is parked behind Eva’s in the driveway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Albert and Eva, only half awake, are sitting up in bed. E mouth is wide open and Albert is looking inside it.

dialogues.speaker: ALBERT
dialogues.text: I've never actually seen wisdom teeth. I didn’t think anyone had them. You have a lot of fillings.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: Do they look like the mercury kind?

dialogues.speaker: ALBERT
dialogues.text: No. Just normal fillings and a couple of crowns. Eva closes her mouth.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: Okay, your turn.

dialogues.speaker: ALBERT
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: Come on. (seductive) Open your mouth.

dialogues.speaker: ALBERT
dialogues.text: Make me. She kisses him and he immediately opens up.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: You're missing a tooth!

dialogues.speaker: ALBERT
dialogues.text: I am.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: It's way back there. You can’t see it.

dialogues.speaker: ALBERT
dialogues.text: I've got to get some kind of hideous bone graft and it costs a fortune and I’ve been putting it off.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: Yeah, my grandma Dee Dee had that.

dialogues.speaker: ALBERT
dialogues.text: Exactly. Grandma Dee Dee. Thank you for that. They kiss when suddenly they hear footsteps.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: Huh? Chloe is standing at the bedroom door.

dialogues.speaker: CHLOE
dialogues.text: Oh my god I’m so sorry.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: Hi honey.

dialogues.speaker: CHLOE
dialogues.text: I didn’t know...

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: This is Chloe, Ellen’s best friend. This is Albert.

dialogues.speaker: ALBERT
dialogues.text: Hi.

dialogues.speaker: CHLOE
dialogues.text: Ellen didn’t answer my texts so I thought she was sleeping.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: She's at her dad’s. You okay?

dialogues.speaker: CHLOE
dialogues.text: Yeah, I just wanted to go out to breakfast.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: (turning to Albert) You hungry?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Albert, Eva and Chloe are eating breakfast.

dialogues.speaker: CHLOE
dialogues.text: So if I tell you a day and a year you'll know what was on?

dialogues.speaker: ALBERT
dialogues.text: Shoot.

dialogues.speaker: CHLOE
dialogues.text: That's crazy! No way. (beat) 1975, channel 4.

dialogues.speaker: ALBERT
dialogues.text: What time?

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: Oh, come on.

dialogues.speaker: CHLOE
dialogues.text: Saturday morning.

dialogues.speaker: ALBERT
dialogues.text: Woody Woodpecker, then Pink Panther then McDuff The Talking Dog - I didn’t like it but watched it anyway, Monster Squad - Land of the Lost and then Big John, Little John, which was like “Big” only weirder.

dialogues.speaker: CHLOE,
dialogues.text: And I thought I watched a lot of TV.

dialogues.speaker: ALBERT
dialogues.text: I really looked forward to the line up.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: What, were you rejected as a child?

dialogues.speaker: ALBERT
dialogues.text: Well, I was kind of raised like a veal. I was put in a dark room and fed and told not to move. They crack up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eva is giving the guy with bad breath, Martin, a massage. mouth breaths as he lies on his back, mouth gaping.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The chatterbox is lying on her back as Eva works on her l

dialogues.speaker: CYNTHIA
dialogues.text: So I said ‘I guess that means you don’t like it’ and she says ‘no, I just might want another size’ but it was definitely her size because she’s petite and big on the top but the thing is I bought it at Nordstrom Rack but I put it in a Neiman Marcus box

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At the house where the guy doesn’t help her - Eva is pull her massage table up the stairs.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: (to herself) That's right, don’t open the door. Pretend you don’t know I’m here...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They walk among the stacks of scripts and audio/video stu

dialogues.speaker: ALBERT
dialogues.text: We have the most comprehensive collection of television shows from 1947 to the present. I make sure things are transferred properly, logged properly. I write blurbs for them, try to make them sound relevant and exciting in case someone younger than fifty wants to put down their phone and see something original and brilliant.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: Like what?

dialogues.speaker: ALBERT
dialogues.text: Like Jack Benny. Or Sid Caesar. Or Dinah Shore. You wouldn’t believe the guests she had on - Betty Grable, Frank Sinatra, Ella Fitzgerald.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: So cool.

dialogues.speaker: ALBERT
dialogues.text: It is. I kind of love it. And if it’s a slow day I get to go downstairs watch a couple episodes of ‘What’s Happening?’ She laughs and they have a kiss.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They approach an open office door.

dialogues.speaker: ALBERT
dialogues.text: This is my office. That’s Bob. Bob looks up from his desk.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: Hey.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: Hey.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: Hey.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They walk into the room where people are watching things video monitors. Eva admires some memorabilia that is plac behind glass.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: Oh, remember Flipper? I always wanted a dolphin as a child.

dialogues.speaker: ALBERT
dialogues.text: That's a lot of work. Suddenly they hear what sounds like a PERSON quietly cryi

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: (whispering) What is that?

dialogues.speaker: ALBERT
dialogues.text: I think it’s somebody watching something. It happens sometimes. Albert Peeks around to see what THE CRYING GUY is looking

dialogues.speaker: ALBERT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Taxi.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: Really?

dialogues.speaker: ALBERT
dialogues.text: It’s probably the one where Alex’s dog died. (beat) You hungry?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eva and Albert stand out front of a burger joint.

dialogues.speaker: ALBERT
dialogues.text: And here she is, right on time. TESS, 18 and lovely, approaches from across the street.

dialogues.speaker: TESS
dialogues.text: Hi Dad!

dialogues.speaker: ALBERT
dialogues.text: (they hug) Tess, this is Eva. Eva, Tess.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: It’s so nice to meet you.

dialogues.speaker: TESS
dialogues.text: You, too!

dialogues.speaker: ALBERT
dialogues.text: So... He gestures that they should enter the restaurant.

dialogues.speaker: TESS
dialogues.text: (disgusted) Seriously.

dialogues.speaker: ALBERT
dialogues.text: They have great chili.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: I love chili.

dialogues.speaker: TESS
dialogues.text: Have you ever been to Lily’s? It’s like, around the corner.

dialogues.speaker: ALBERT
dialogues.text: (beat) Lily’s it is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The three eat lunch in the upscale restaurant. Albert eat steak while Tess and Eva have salads.

dialogues.speaker: TESS
dialogues.text: I'll be studying fashion design.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: Well, obviously you have great taste.

dialogues.speaker: TESS
dialogues.text: Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: ALBERT
dialogues.text: (to Tess) Eva has a daughter just starting college too.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: She’s going to Sarah Lawrence. English and History. She loves History. But I think she wants to be a writer.

dialogues.speaker: TESS
dialogues.text: God, Sarah Lawrence is not what it used to be. (beat) I mean, I'm sure it’s still good, it’s just gone downhill a lot in the last few years. Some of my - let’s just say - not so smart friends ~ just got in. I was shocked.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: Uh huh.

dialogues.speaker: ALBERT
dialogues.text: I’m sure some very smart people go there.

dialogues.speaker: TESS
dialogues.text: I know. I’m just saying.

dialogues.speaker: ALBERT
dialogues.text: (joking) And I’m just saying you should stay home and go to school around here. She glares at him.

dialogues.speaker: TESS
dialogues.text: At least you’re honest about it. Mom acts like she’s so excited to be on her own again but I don’t buy it.

dialogues.speaker: ALBERT
dialogues.text: Okay, let’s lighten up on Mom. She’s all right. And don’t judge until you have kids.

dialogues.speaker: TESS
dialogues.text: Except that I’m not having any.

dialogues.speaker: ALBERT
dialogues.text: (upset) What? How can you know that?

dialogues.speaker: TESS
dialogues.text: I want a career. Anyway, I hate kids. Eva looks at Albert, who looks destroyed.

dialogues.speaker: ALBERT
dialogues.text: Well, right about now we have that in common!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They come out of the restaurant. Tess walks ahead.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: (trying to comfort him) She doesn’t know what she’s talking about. She’s too young to know what she wants. Tess sees THREE FRIENDS coming down the street.

dialogues.speaker: TESS
dialogues.text: Cory! Hey you guys! They all stop and chat. Each friend is chic and adult- looking.

dialogues.speaker: TESS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (turning to Albert) Dad, I’m going to get a coffee, okay? She kisses him and shakes Eva's hand.

dialogues.speaker: TESS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: So nice to meet you.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: Yeah, you too!

dialogues.speaker: ALBERT
dialogues.text: Be careful. Tess walks off. ALBERT (CONT’D) She has lots of friends.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: Do you think they have threesomes?

dialogues.speaker: ALBERT
dialogues.text: What?! Why would you say that?

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: It's what the kids are doing these days.

dialogues.speaker: ALBERT
dialogues.text: Oh my god.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: Right? (contemplating) I'm afraid that window has closed.

dialogues.speaker: ALBERT
dialogues.text: There was a window?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ellen is climbing into Eva’s bed. They snuggle.

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN
dialogues.text: Hey. How was the daughter?

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: Kind of awful. A real snob.

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN
dialogues.text: That's too bad.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: I wonder what your roommate’s gonna be like. Want me to call her parents?

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: You hungry?

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN
dialogues.text: Not really.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: What did you eat yesterday?

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN
dialogues.text: I don’t know.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: Think. Tell me everything you ate.

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN
dialogues.text: Cereal. A banana.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: Where’d you get the banana?

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN
dialogues.text: (getting up) You're crazy.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: What did you have for lunch?

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN
dialogues.text: Bye! EXT. MARIANNE’S BACKYARD - DAY Eva is giving Marianne a massage on the patio. EXT. MARIANNE’S BACKYARD - LATER Post massage, they sit on lounge chairs and sip iced tea.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: He's kind of flabby and middle aged but I don’t care. I'm flabby and middle aged.

dialogues.speaker: MARIANNE,
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: It’s funny, our middle aged-ness is comforting and sexy to me. Isn’t that so incredibly sad? But sort of good, too?

dialogues.speaker: MARIANNE
dialogues.text: I think that’s what my ex always wanted from me. To accept his belly and all of his quirks. But in the end I was totally repulsed by him sexually. He was kind of terrible in bed. Very clumsy.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: Oh no! That's awful!

dialogues.speaker: MARIANNE
dialogues.text: Oh, just a sec. Marianne runs in the house and returns with her book of poetry. She hands it to Eva. MARIANNE (CONT’D) It’s my last copy, but I want you to have it.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: (examining it) Wow. You sure?

dialogues.speaker: MARIANNE
dialogues.text: Absolutely.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: I'ma little intimidated, I’m not real good with poetry.

dialogues.speaker: MARIANNE
dialogues.text: Just let them wash over you. Don’t try and understand them.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: Believe me, I won't.

dialogues.speaker: MARIANNE
dialogues.text: You know, I love being with you. Would it be weird if we hung out, as friends?

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: I would love that.

dialogues.speaker: MARIANNE
dialogues.text: Me, too. (beat) Please, have some salsa. These tomatoes are amazing. Marianne pushes the bowl to Eva.

dialogues.speaker: MARIANNE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: But watch out. I put in a ton of onions, one of many upsides to my divorce.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: What do you mean?

dialogues.speaker: MARIANNE
dialogues.text: My ex-husband hated onions so he'd take a chip and swirl it around and around and around until all the onions were on one side - Marianne shows her, scraping and swirling with disgusted exaggeration. MARIANNE (CONT’D) It kind of made me sick. Eva looks at her, alarmed.

dialogues.speaker: TESS, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Mom?

dialogues.speaker: MARIANNE
dialogues.text: (quietly to Eva) My daughter’s not feeling well. I’11 be right back. Marianne gets up and Tess, in her pajamas, meets her in t dining room. Eva looks up and sees them talking quietly. IT’S TESS!

dialogues.speaker: ALBERTS TESS
dialogues.text: Eva's stunned, freaked. She hides behind a bush. Marianne brings Tess outside. MARIANNE (CONT’D) I want you to meet my friend. Eva!? Weird, where'd she go?

dialogues.speaker: TESS
dialogues.text: I want to go back to bed. Tess gives her little kiss.

dialogues.speaker: MARIANNE
dialogues.text: You have bad breath.

dialogues.speaker: TESS
dialogues.text: I'm sick! Tess goes off. Eva comes out of the bushes.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: I’m just admiring all of your plantings! This one is so big!

dialogues.speaker: MARIANNE
dialogues.text: I wanted you to meet Tess...

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: Oh...

dialogues.speaker: MARIANNE
dialogues.text: Anyway, I better get going.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: oh, sure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: EXT. MARIANNE’S HOUSE - DAY Eva rushes out of Marianne’s house lugging her massage ta Marianne stands at the front door.

dialogues.speaker: MARIANNE
dialogues.text: So, should we do something? Next week?

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: Absolutely. Yes! Marianne gives her a long, affectionate hug.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eva drives away from Marianne’s, her mind racing. She sto at a stop sign, taking deep breaths.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eva is VIDEO CHATTING WITH SARAH.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: Remember that new client of mine that I think is perfect? Marianne?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sarah is at her desk.

dialogues.speaker: EVA'S VOICE
dialogues.text: It turns out she’s Albert's ex-wife! Can you believe this? I am not shitting you.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: That’s an unbelievable coincidence. What are you going to do? The light behind Sarah’s desk goes on.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: Damn it your light just went on. Call me later? They shut off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She makes dinner as Ellen and Chloe come in.

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN
dialogues.text: Hi Ma.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: Did you take off your shoes?

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN
dialogues.text: No. Since when do I have to?

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: I want to start doing that. It’s cleaner. Both Chloe and Ellen kick off their shoes.

dialogues.speaker: EVA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Socks too. They roll their eyes. EVA (CONT’D) Listen to this. Turns out I’ve been giving massages to Albert’s ex-wife.

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN
dialogues.text: How weird.

dialogues.speaker: CHLOE
dialogues.text: So weird.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: I've been listening to this woman say the worst things about the one guy that I’m starting to really like. I pictured her ex like this fat, irritating slob, and it’s Albert. (realizing) Fat Albert.

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN
dialogues.text: Who?

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: Oh, it’s just a cartoon. A cartoon!

dialogues.speaker: CHLOE
dialogues.text: But he’s so not like that.

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN
dialogues.text: How do you know?

dialogues.speaker: CHLOE
dialogues.text: We all had breakfast the other day. He’s really sweet and funny.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: You liked him?

dialogues.speaker: CHLOE
dialogues.text: Totally.

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: You weren’t home, honey, so we had breakfast. That’s all.

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN
dialogues.text: But I haven't even met him.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: You will.

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN
dialogues.text: What does this woman say about him?

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: Ugh. Terrible things. She thought he was disgusting. A wimp with his daughter. Useless in bed.

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN
dialogues.text: (gzossed out) Mom!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eva, dressed for hiking, and Marianne dressed for hiking/cocktails, walk up the hill. MANY OTHER WALKERS pa them.

dialogues.speaker: MARIANNE
dialogues.text: I date sometimes, but it’s so hard to meet people. I’m not attracted to anybody.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: And you weren’t attracted to your husband? That must have been difficult.

dialogues.speaker: MARIANNE
dialogues.text: I tried really hard. He’d go on so many diets and cheat all the time and act shocked when he got fatter. It was so irritating. It almost wasn’t the weight that bugged me, it was his behavior about the weight. Just then TWO FEMALE HIKERS (30's), who are going in the opposite direction, give Marianne a double-take.

dialogues.speaker: FEMALE HIKER
dialogues.text: Excuse me, are you Marianne Hope?

dialogues.speaker: MARIANNE,
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: FEMALE HIKER
dialogues.text: Oh my god.

dialogues.speaker: OTHER FEMALE HIKER
dialogues.text: You are our idol. We were just talking about you!

dialogues.speaker: FEMALE HIKER
dialogues.text: We admire you so much. I can’t believe we‘re meeting you! Marianne shakes both of their hands.

dialogues.speaker: MARIANNE
dialogues.text: Hello, so nice. Thank you so much.

dialogues.speaker: FEMALE HIKER
dialogues.text: You have no idea how much this means to us. She gave me Beautiful Fruit when my mom died and it literally saved me.

dialogues.speaker: MARIANNE
dialogues.text: How wonderful. I’m so sorry. (ending it) Blessings. The hikers go down the hill, changed women. Marianne and continue hiking up.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: Blessings! (beat) It’s so cool you saved her! Marianne just smiles. Eva brings the conversation around.

dialogues.speaker: EVA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: But he never got obese, right?

dialogues.speaker: MARIANNE
dialogues.text: It depends on your definition of obese.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: Oh. Otherwise you liked him, more or less?

dialogues.speaker: MARIANNE
dialogues.text: Unfortunately, less. He did so many things that got on my nerves.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: Like what?

dialogues.speaker: MARIANNE
dialogues.text: (beat) I’m sorry I’m being so negative. But I don't really have anyone else I can bitch to about this kind of thing.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: You can completely bitch to me.

dialogues.speaker: MARIANNE
dialogues.text: Thank you. I trust you.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: (beat) Oh good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sarah’s living room has been partially rearranged. She’s moving decorative pillows around, trying to find the righ spot. Eva helps her.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: What’s wrong with you? She can find another masseuse.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: I feel bad. She doesn’t have close friends and I’m like, it. (beat) I feel so pulled in. She’s like a human Trip Advisor.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: Albert's not a hotel.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: No, but if you could avoid staying in a bad one, wouldn't you?

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: Oh my god.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: She’s said so many bad things about him. She knows what she’s talking about. She’s very smart.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: So are you. And she’s not perfect.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: But maybe she’s ultimately right.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: Are you ultimately right about Peter? Just because you didn’t want him, does that make him unlovable?

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: By anyone normal. Sarah gives up.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: You didn’t say anything about my new furniture arrangement.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: (looking around) I don’t remember how it was.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: Better or worse? Will comes in the front door and looks around the room.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Do you like it?

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: Honey. Why do you keep doing this?

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: She’s filling a hole.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: I’1l fill your hole.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: Different hole. Will shrugs and walks away.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: Missing out. Fun times...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eva comes outside and walks up to a FORD FIESTA parked at curb. She leans down to get in, seeing Albert in the driv seat.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: Who's car is this?

dialogues.speaker: ALBERT
dialogues.text: Oh, Tess is getting hers fixed, so this is a rental.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: So why do you have it?

dialogues.speaker: ALBERT
dialogues.text: I'm letting her drive mine. She likes it better. Eva gets inside, tense.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: (under her breath) I bet she does.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eva and Albert are in their seats but the movie hasn’t started yet. He’s shaking his large bucket of popcorn.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: Why are you shaking that?

dialogues.speaker: ALBERT
dialogues.text: It spreads the butter around.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: You put more butter on it?  ENOUGH SAID ery

dialogues.speaker: ALBERT
dialogues.text: Just the butter. I didn’t more butter. Self conscious, he eats his popcorn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The movie is playing.

dialogues.speaker: ALBERT
dialogues.text: (talking about the movie) I saw that actor once. He was about three feet tall. Eva shrugs, not wanting to talk. ALBERT (CONT’D) Do you like this movie? Eva nods. ALBERT (CONT’D) What is she wearing? It looks like her grandmother crocheted something and she put it on her - A GUY in another row shushes him.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: You should whisper.

dialogues.speaker: ALBERT
dialogues.text: I am whispering. Eva clenches her teeth and tries to watch the film.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: That’s not a whisper.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Albert and Eva have just finished making love.

dialogues.speaker: ALBERT
dialogues.text: I’m going to ask you something and I really want you to be honest.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: (worried) Okay.

dialogues.speaker: ALBERT
dialogues.text: Can you breathe when I’m on top of you?

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: Of course.

dialogues.speaker: ALBERT
dialogues.text: I’m planning on losing some weight, by the way. I know I need to.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: (beat) Oh? (beat) Was it ever an issue with your wife?

dialogues.speaker: ALBERT
dialogues.text: Sometimes I ate just to drive her nuts. They lie there quietly for a bit. His breathing is loud.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: You have a cold?

dialogues.speaker: ALBERT
dialogues.text: No. I broke my nose a couple of times. My doctor says that at this point my nose is purely ornamental.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: (laughing) You gonna get it fixed?

dialogues.speaker: ALBERT
dialogues.text: Yeah, right after my missing tooth. (beat) By the way, I think Tess really liked you.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: Yeah?

dialogues.speaker: ALBERT
dialogues.text: Yeah. I could tell.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: (not liking Tess) She seems neat.

dialogues.speaker: ALBERT
dialogues.text: I know she can be a little obnoxious, but she’s figuring it all out. She’s got a good heart.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He pulls her to him. ALBERT (CONT’D) I kind of adore you already.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eva's toes, as Chloe carefully and slowly paints them a p blue. She tries to keep her feet still but it’s hard.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: What happened with you and Chris? Chloe blushes.

dialogues.speaker: EVA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What? You can tell me.

dialogues.speaker: CHLOE,
dialogues.text: We did it.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: Oh my god, how was it?!

dialogues.speaker: CHLOE
dialogues.text: (beat) Nice. I think. It was good.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: Awww. Congratulations. I’m so glad it was nice.

dialogues.speaker: CHLOE
dialogues.text: Even if we don’t stay together, I’m glad I got it over with, you know? I’m really glad I took your advice to - Just then Ellen comes home and is surprised to see Chloe.

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN
dialogues.text: When did you get here?

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: A few minutes ago. (beat) I told her to wait.

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN
dialogues.text: I’ve been wanting to paint your toes for ten years. I thought you were too ticklish.

dialogues.speaker: CHLOE,
dialogues.text: She’s in love.

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN
dialogues.text: So that makes you not ticklish?

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: You weren't here. Sweetie. Be with us. Ellen leaves. Eva and Chloe exchange an “oops” look.

dialogues.speaker: EVA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Ellen! Come back! But there’s no response.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marianne sits up, having just been massaged. Eva is straightening up.

dialogues.speaker: MARIANNE
dialogues.text: Crazy morning. I got a wonderful call from Joni Mitchell. She read the galleys for my new collection and loved it.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: You’re friends with Joni Mitchell?

dialogues.speaker: MARIANNE
dialogues.text: Yeah, we've been for a while. And I met a nice guy, We went out last night. He’s in great shape, he really takes care of himself. He’s vegan. He actually read my work before he knew me. Isn’t that cool?

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: A poetry reading vegan? Oh my god. Marianne heads to the kitchen and keeps talking.

dialogues.speaker: MARIANNE
dialogues.text: We‘re going out again tomorrow. I hope it goes well. I tend to get my hopes up too early. With Albert, it always felt like a bait and switch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When we first started dating, I thought, ‘He’s mature! He can buy a house?’

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: This house?

dialogues.speaker: MARIANNE
dialogues.text: Yes! And he cooked! He made me this dish, spaghetti with eggplant and mozzarella.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: That sounds delicious!

dialogues.speaker: MARIANNE
dialogues.text: But it turned out it was the only thing he knew how to cook.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: Uh huh.

dialogues.speaker: MARIANNE,
dialogues.text: And he has no friends. Neither do I -

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: Me and Joni.

dialogues.speaker: MARIANNE,
dialogues.text: That's true! EXT. ALBERT’S HOUSE - EVENING Eva knocks on Albert's door. He opens it and beams when h sees her.

dialogues.speaker: ALBERT
dialogues.text: Hil (beat) Hungry? INT. ALBERT’S KITCHEN/DINING ROOM - EVENING Albert presents Eva with a plate of food.

dialogues.speaker: ALBERT
dialogues.text: I hope you like spaghetti with eggplant and mozzarella! He sets it before her and she looks sick. After a moment, eats.

dialogues.speaker: ALBERT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Is everything okay?

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: This is actually pretty damn amazing. He sits with her.

dialogues.speaker: ALBERT
dialogues.text: How was work today?

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: It was good. I had two massages.

dialogues.speaker: ALBERT
dialogues.text: Tell me. Non stop talking? Barnacles? Erections?

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: It was a nice woman in Santa Monica. (beat) She talks a lot about her ex husband. Long pause. Eva is about to tell him the truth.

dialogues.speaker: EVA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Albert -

dialogues.speaker: ALBERT
dialogues.text: Let’s hope it wasn’t my ex wife! She coughs, miserable. Stuck.

dialogues.speaker: ALBERT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (beat) I have a little present for you.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: You do? She‘s nervous. He places a small box in front of her.

dialogues.speaker: ALBERT
dialogues.text: Now, it’s just a little present. Eva opens the box and lifts up a pretty, simple necklace.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: Oh my god.

dialogues.speaker: ALBERT
dialogues.text: I just saw it and thought of you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He caresses her neck. ALBERT (CONT’D) This beautiful, wonderful part. He gets up and puts it on her, kisses her. He can tell something is wrong.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: You like it on me? Thank you soooo much.

dialogues.speaker: ALBERT
dialogues.text: Maybe I shouldn’t have. Is it too soon?

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: No, it’s lovely. Thank you. EXT/INT. ALBERT’S BEDROOM - NIGHT Eva and Albert are making love in the dark. He accidently jabs her.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: Ouch!

dialogues.speaker: ALBERT
dialogues.text: I’m so sorry.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: No worries. He does it again.

dialogues.speaker: EVA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Shit. Ouch.

dialogues.speaker: ALBERT
dialogues.text: What am I doing?

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: It’s just - your elbow - that’s better, oh.

dialogues.speaker: ALBERT
dialogues.text: Good. Eva giggles.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: Your beard - it’s so ticklish.

dialogues.speaker: ALBERT
dialogues.text: oh, sorry.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: That's okay. They kiss some more. He climbs on top.

dialogues.speaker: EVA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: ! My hair!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ow! My hai Albert stops and reaches for the light, which he flips on

dialogues.speaker: ALBERT
dialogues.text: (upset) Okay. I don’t know what I’m doing, but this is not going well. Why don’t we just stop. He looks at her as she sighs deeply. INT. ALBERT’S BATHROOM - LATER THAT NIGHT Eva is standing in Albert's messy bathroom. She looks at grimy sink. He has about SIX toothbrushes in his cup. She bends down to the cabinet and opens it. Cob webs, dus Ancient things. About FOUR bottles of mouthwash with vary degrees left. She stares at them, disturbed. INT. ALBERT’S BEDROOM - NIGHT Eva comes out of the bathroom and sits on the bed.

dialogues.speaker: ALBERT
dialogues.text: You look cute in my robe. Everything all right?

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: You have four hundred mouthwashes.

dialogues.speaker: ALBERT
dialogues.text: Uh, yeah. I buy them, I forget to use them, I buy more...

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: Why do you have so many toothbrushes?

dialogues.speaker: ALBERT
dialogues.text: I don’t know. I only use one.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: So why don’t you throw the others out?

dialogues.speaker: ALBERT
dialogues.text: (beat) They're my friends? Eva lies next to him and he snuggles in. ALBERT (CONT’D) Should we give it another shot?

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: Oh, I’m just so tired. Is that okay?

dialogues.speaker: ALBERT
dialogues.text: Yeah. It’s okay. He goes to kiss her but she’s turning over, away from him

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PETER AND FRAN (Eva’s ex and his new wife), Ellen, Chloe, Sarah and Will. The food has not yet been served.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: So proud of you, honey. Everyone toasts to Ellen.

dialogues.speaker: FRAN
dialogues.text: We are. Here’s some graduation money. She hands her an envelope.

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN
dialogues.text: Thanks so much you guys.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: (joking) It's in fives.

dialogues.speaker: CHLOE
dialogues.text: Thanks for including me tonight.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: You had a fight with your mom?

dialogues.speaker: CHLOE
dialogues.text: Huge.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: Where’s your dad?

dialogues.speaker: CHLOE
dialogues.text: He lives in San Diego but you'd think it was across the Pacific. He never comes up. I don’t care. He remarried a really weird woman. She never talks.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: (maybe a little drunk) Hear, hear for second marriages. Will gives his wife a strange look.

dialogues.speaker: FRAN
dialogues.text: It's kind of true, though. It’s good when everyone is a little older and wiser.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: Maybe second marriages work because people have figured out how to compromise.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: Or behave, perhaps.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Thanks everyone!

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: No one is talking about you.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: Not you personally. In general. If I got married again I'd be on the lookout for what was going to be our inevitable problems.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: Odd conversation.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: It’s true. Everyone is crazy.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: So, maybe don’t get married again.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Said the first husband.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: I'm not saying I will. I’m just saying.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: (to Fran) What was your first husband like?

dialogues.speaker: FRAN
dialogues.text: He was actually a lovely man. Just not for me.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: Oh. Very grown up!

dialogues.speaker: FRAN
dialogues.text: He passed away. Two years ago. Peter attracts a WAITER.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Excuse me, could we have more bread?

dialogues.speaker: WAITER
dialogues.text: Of course.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: Oh no, not more bread.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Why not?

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: I don’t want to eat it.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: So don’t. (to waiter) More bread, please? The waiter leaves.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: Are you even going to eat it?

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: I don’t know. But the others might.

dialogues.speaker: FRAN
dialogues.text: I probably will.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: Me, too.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Bread eater, another bread eater...

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: Okay, sorry.

dialogues.speaker: EVA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (like an interview) So, Fran. You eat bread.

dialogues.speaker: FRAN
dialogues.text: It's true.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: (to Peter) Does that mean you can keep cookies in the house?

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: I can.

dialogues.speaker: CHLOE
dialogues.text: What are you guys talking about?

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: I have a little trouble controlling myself when it comes to sweets or bread, so when Peter brought something like cookies or chocolate or good bread home I would eat all of it and then hate myself.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: And me, for buying it in the first place.

dialogues.speaker: CHLOE
dialogues.text: So, did you stop buying it?

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: I did.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: But he was angry.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: I was not.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: Well, just a little.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: (to Peter) You should be angry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why should you be deprived because she can't control herself?

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: Because she’s his wife and he’s trying to help her?

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: But is that really helping her?

dialogues.speaker: SARAH AND EVA
dialogues.text: Yes!

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: Not if we want her to learn how to control herself.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: We

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: (rolling her eyes) Oh my god, here it comes.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: It's not fair to him.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: Why does everything have to be fair?! What are you, six!?

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: Come on, let’s keep it nice.

dialogues.speaker: FRAN
dialogues.text: (shrugging) I just forget the cookies are there.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: That's why you're married to Peter and I’m not. The WAITER COMES BY and puts the bread on the table. takes some.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everyone exits the restaurant. Eva 67  ENOUGH SAID os

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: (to Peter) Nobody ate the bread, by the way.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: You did.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: Exactly. She starts to walk away but stops herself. EVA (CONT’D) What do you say to people when they asked why we got divorced?

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: I usually just say we probably shouldn’‘t have been together.
