dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: But Fran knows everything. I mean, you’ve talked about me. He looks at her as if to say “duh.”

dialogues.speaker: EVA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Of course. She’s your wife. Eva and Peter join the others. While they all chat and la Eva stares at her ex husband, growing pensive and lonely.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eva sits on the couch knitting a blanket. She’s also pori over her and Peter’s WEDDING ALBUM. They look so happy an young. Ellen and Chloe come through wearing pajamas.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: Do you know I started this blanket when you were five. Somehow I liked this color. But I’m going to finish it so you can take it with you.

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN
dialogues.text: Maybe I should buy another, just in case. The girls glance at the wedding album.

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Why are you looking at this?

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: I don’t know. I pulled it out. (staring hard at a picture) I’m trying to remember what I knew. Did I already know those things about your dad, the things that we would fight about?

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN
dialogues.text: Probably not.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: I think I did. I think I always knew them. Or felt them. (beat) I didn’t pay attention. Eva snaps out of her reverie and kisses Ellen.

dialogues.speaker: EVA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: But look what I got. She kisses Ellen.

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN
dialogues.text: ‘Night Mom. Eva holds onto her.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: Stay up with me. Let’s cuddle.

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN
dialogues.text: I’m tired.

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Come on, Chloe.

dialogues.speaker: CHLOE
dialogues.text: (xe: knitting) Is that hard?

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: Not at all. Want to learn? (more to Ellen) I've been wanting to teach Ellen for the longest time... Ellen goes out of the room and Chloe sits next to Eva. Ev cell phone rings on the coffee table and Chloe leans over look at it.

dialogues.speaker: CHLOE,
dialogues.text: Albert. After a beat, Eva shakes her head “no,” as in - don’t pic up.

dialogues.speaker: CHLOE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You're still seeing his wife?

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: (defensive) She has a bad shoulder. And no friends. Chloe looks at her, disapproving.

dialogues.speaker: EVA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Don’t look at me like that. I’m screwed up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marianne, with her phone in her hand, and looking slightl unhinged, lets Eva in.

dialogues.speaker: MARIANNE
dialogues.text: Sorry. In the middle of some bullshit. Come in. Eva takes off her shoes and sets up the massage table whi Marianne shouts into the phone.

dialogues.speaker: MARIANNE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: How many times do we have to discuss this? You did agree. Albert, I was there, I remember. It’s all worked out...Fine. Good bye. Ughhhhh!!! I can’t wait til I don’t have to talk to him anymore!!

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: What happened?

dialogues.speaker: MARIANNE
dialogues.text: (pouring wine) He thinks he should take her to school, not me. We already agreed it would be me. Tess wants it to be me. She told me.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: Could you both take her?

dialogues.speaker: MARIANNE
dialogues.text: I don’t think so. He’s a wreck about her leaving and she doesn’t need that kind of energy. They sit across from one another at the table.

dialogues.speaker: MARIANNE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: He focuses so much on her and she can feel it.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: Isn't that kind of nice, though? That he focuses?

dialogues.speaker: MARIANNE
dialogues.text: Maybe if he had a girlfriend, or something like that, it would balance it out. But I can’t see that happening. Nope.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: Why not?

dialogues.speaker: MARIANNE
dialogues.text: He’s just - a loser, you know? I hate to use that word, but it fits. Eva nods, her heart sinking.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: How so?

dialogues.speaker: MARIANNE
dialogues.text: He just never got his life together. Okay, for instance ~ and this is just typical Albert. When I met him he had nothing next to his bed, like a table or something. Nothing. He’d put everything on the floor. And I thought, this is cute, kind of bohemian or whatever. But when we got married I got us night tables, you know, like normal people. Then I was in his house, I don’t know, a year ago. And I saw all his stuff on the floor again. I mean, I took the night tables, granted, but you'd think he’d get some new ones. Metaphorically speaking, he’s not building a life for himself. You know what I mean? The phone rings and she looks at it. 7

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MARIANNE (CONT’D) Ugh. That‘s him again. I’m not picking up.

dialogues.speaker: ALBERT ON PHONE MACHINE
dialogues.text: Please pick up the phone, Marianne. We’ve not resolved anything.

dialogues.speaker: MARIANNE
dialogues.text: I’m sorry you have to hear this. This is so embarrassing.

dialogues.speaker: ALBERT ON PHONE MACHINE
dialogues.text: I know you're there. Fine. Don’t deal. He hangs up. Eva is cringing, wishing she wasn’t hearing this.

dialogues.speaker: MARIANNE
dialogues.text: (sad) You know, these are all little things. Ultimately, I think I just never felt understood by him. He didn’t understand my poetry. He just never got me. (beat) Have you ever felt like someone got you? Eva thinks and breaks into a bittersweet smile, realizing much Albert does get her. MARIANNE (CONT’D) What about the flabby guy?

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: Yeah. Maybe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eva is video chatting with Sarah, who is in her office. (

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: I need you to meet him.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: I mean, I’d love to meet him. But not so you can decide what you think of him.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: Please? I feel like I’m losing all perspective.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: Exactly. You don’t need someone else’s. I don’t want to get in the middle of this -

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: Please?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Albert, Eva, Sarah and Will sit around the living room drinking wine. They help themselves to a cheese plate, an chips and guacamole.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: No flowers, no little dots.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: I once bought sheets that had stars on them and he -

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: (in baby voice) Little stars and moons and suns -

dialogues.speaker: ALBERT
dialogues.text: Oh no.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: Right? Why do women like things that look like they belong to children?

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: I love doll house furniture. I would eat it if I could.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: Sometimes I think I'd like to be single just so I can have girly sheets.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: You would like that, wouldn’t you?

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: I'm kidding.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: I hope so.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: (pouring herself more wine) I have flowered sheets and they’re not all they’re cracked up to be.  ENOUGH SAID v4

dialogues.speaker: ALBERT
dialogues.text: I like your flowered sheets.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: Don’t sell me out, man.

dialogues.speaker: ALBERT
dialogues.text: We‘re new. At this point I‘d probably like her sheets if they had little Mussolini’s on them.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: Hey, get some night tables and we'll talk. (beat) He’s got normal sheets but no night tables.

dialogues.speaker: ALBERT
dialogues.text: So, I have no night tables.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: Well, maybe it’s a metaphor. Or maybe it’s not! Albert flinches a bit - that hurt. He reaches for the guacamole and starts to swirl the onions to the side. Eva watches, wondering if this bothers her or not.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: You know, I make a million compromises. Not having flowery sheets is not a big deal.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: (taken aback) I know. I know you make compromises.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: You do? What do you think they are?

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: Will, this isn’t the time.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: Sometimes I wish I was with someone who was more interested in History.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: (beat, confused) What?

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: History.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: Okay...

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: I’m just saying. Very uncomfortable. Cathy, the maid, comes into the livin room and takes the empty guacamole bowl.

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: More guacamole?

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: Not for me.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: or me.

dialogues.speaker: ALBERT
dialogues.text: I'd love some, thank you. Cathy goes into the kitchen.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: You know how many calories are in guacamole?

dialogues.speaker: ALBERT
dialogues.text: Ten?

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: (mortified) Leave the guy alone. He likes his guacamole.

dialogues.speaker: ALBERT
dialogues.text: (to Cathy, in the kitchen) Never mind the guac! I/1l just stick with the cheese!

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: (drinking MORE wine) You know what I’m going to get you for a present? I’m going to get you a calorie book.

dialogues.speaker: ALBERT
dialogues.text: Please don’t.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: Yeah, a calorie book as a gift isn’t so good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mid dinner, lots of wine.

dialogues.speaker: ALBERT
dialogues.text: Eva tells me you’re a therapist.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: Tell us about your weirdest patient.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: What? You know I can’t.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: She can’t.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: She can. You don’t have to name names, mate!

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: (to Albert) She’s so uptight about confidentiality.

dialogues.speaker: ALBERT
dialogues.text: Shouldn’t she be?

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: (beat) I have this one patient who picks his nose and eats it.

dialogues.speaker: ALBERT
dialogues.text: In front of you!?

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: Is he a child?

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: Are you making this up? Sarah looks at him like he’s crazy.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: It’s so gross and distracting. He does it in this way that he thinks I can’t see, but of course I can. Everyone is grossed out.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: And I’m not going to tell you who it is, but he’s famous. They shriek.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Really famous.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: Tell us!

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: I bet I know who it is.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: You don't.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: You have to tell us!

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: I can’t tell you either.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: Not fair!

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: (guilty) Okay no more. Show's over. Eva pours more wine for herself.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: I like being drunk. I think it’s highly overrated. I mean underrated!

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: You're shouting.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: I am?

dialogues.speaker: ALBERT
dialogues.text: You are, a little.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: I just don’t want you to wake the little people.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: Oh sorry. Yeah. You want to know something funny? Albert doesn’t know how to whisper.

dialogues.speaker: ALBERT
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: Go ahead, show them.

dialogues.speaker: ALBERT
dialogues.text: What are you talking about?

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: Please? It’s funny.

dialogues.speaker: ALBERT
dialogues.text: (trying) This is whispering.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: That's a whisper.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: No, it wasn’t.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: (whispering) Can 1?

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: (whispering) What about me?

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: Yes. Everyone turns to Albert. It looks like he’s going to hav try to whisper again.

dialogues.speaker: ALBERT
dialogues.text: (not whispering) This is whispering. Eva cracks up, thinking this is hilarious.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: Not at all. That is not a whisper!

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: You're picking on him.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: I am not!

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: You are.

dialogues.speaker: ALBERT
dialogues.text: You kind of are.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: (beat) I'm sorry. I just never met anybody who couldn't whisper.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everyone’s in the kitchen, pitching in to clean with Cath Cathy puts some stuff in the dishwasher and then goes bac into the dining room, leaving everyone alone for a second Sarah glares at Cathy’s back and Will notices.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: (quietly) You're not allowed to complain about her anymore. Sarah is holding up a softball.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: Why is this in the kitchen drawer? Is someone playing ball in the kitchen? Just then Cathy comes back in. Everyone smiles. Sarah tak beat and then holds up the ball.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Cathy?

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: Yes?

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: Did you put this ball in the drawer? Eva and Albert instantly look away and act busy.

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: Maybe one of the kids put it there?

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: (taking the ball) Of course they did. Sarah, give Cathy a break.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: But I think you put it there. I find weird stuff in these drawers all the time.

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: I clean up the best I can.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: I just don’t understand the thought process.

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: You want the counter to be clean.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: Yes, but not by shoving shit in the wrong drawers. I mean, why would the ball belong in the kitchen? How is that helpful to me?

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: That’s enough. He pulls on Sarah’s shoulders.

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: You know what Missus Sarah - I find your crap everywhere and you think I know where to put it?

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: (scared) No?

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: You leave your things all over the house, you leave food out overnight, you let your children write on the walls! You floss your teeth and you leave it! You clean your own house. She finds her purse and jacket.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CATHY (CONT’D) You people disgust me. But you're nice, Mr. Will.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: Thanks Cathy! She walks past Eva and Albert and slams the door behind h

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: Oh my god!

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: It would have been kinder to fire her.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: Um, my timing might be a little off, but... I think I put the ball in the drawer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Albert drives.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: That wasn’t a very fun evening, was it? I’m sorry. Albert doesn’t respond.

dialogues.speaker: EVA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Quite a finale, though!

dialogues.speaker: ALBERT
dialogues.text: (pissed) Why do you care if I can’t whisper?

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: ALBERT
dialogues.text: What was all that? That was so embarrassing.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: I was just kidding around.

dialogues.speaker: ALBERT
dialogues.text: (beat) A calorie book? You want to buy me a calorie book?

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: (beat) I wasn't really going to buy you a calorie book.

dialogues.speaker: ALBERT
dialogues.text: I thought you actually liked me.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: (confused) I do like you.

dialogues.speaker: ALBERT
dialogues.text: Why do I feel like I just spent the evening with my ex-wife. Eva looks at the street.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: Wait. Are you driving me home?

dialogues.speaker: ALBERT
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: Are you staying over?

dialogues.speaker: ALBERT
dialogues.text: No. Not tonight.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: Oh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eva gets out of the car and Albert drives off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eva comes in and dumps her purse. She’s startled to see C lying down in the living room. But kind of relieved.

dialogues.speaker: CHLOE
dialogues.text: (sitting up) Hi. Ellen went out with friends but I don’t want to go home. Is it okay?

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: I’m actually glad you’re here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They curl up together.

dialogues.speaker: CHLOE
dialogues.text: I feel so much more comfortable at your house.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: You know, you're welcome to stay in Ellen’s room when she’s gone. You'd have to talk to your mom but it’s just gonna be empty.

dialogues.speaker: CHLOE
dialogues.text: Really?

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: Sure.

dialogues.speaker: CHLOE
dialogues.text: That would be awesome. Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The TV is on and Eva and Chloe are asleep among their knitting. Ellen comes in the front door and stands over t

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN
dialogues.text: (to Chloe) Excuse me, Chloe, but could I have my mom back? They sit up, groggy.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: We were watching something and I guess we just passed out. Ellen goes to her room, angry.

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN
dialogues.text: For all I know you'll be asking her to move into my room when I’m gone! She leaves the room and they hear THE BEDROOM DOOR SLAM S

dialogues.speaker: CHLOE
dialogues.text: I’m sorry.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: Not your fault, sweetie.

dialogues.speaker: CHLOE
dialogues.text: I better go home. INT. ELLEN’S ROOM - MOMENTS LATER - NIGHT Ellen is packing things into boxes. Eva comes in and sits the bed.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: Honey. Chloe is needy.

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN
dialogues.text: Who's needy? (beat) I’m guess I’m trying to feel a little separate, you know, to sort of prepare. But instead I just feel lonely and anxious and Chloe’s always here!

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: I’m so sorry. Eva holds out her arms.

dialogues.speaker: EVA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Honey. You know you're my baby. Ellen ignores her and continues to put things in piles.

dialogues.speaker: EVA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Please let me hug you. Let mama hug you. More ignoring. Eva sighs.

dialogues.speaker: EVA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (beat) Can I see what Dad and Fran got you? Ellen points to a new blanket.

dialogues.speaker: EVA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I'm going to finish my blanket. What else did they get you? Ellen holds up some nice hangers.

dialogues.speaker: EVA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Oh, those are good. They don’t take up a lot of room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ellen continues putting clothes in boxes and Eva sits the not knowing what else to say. EXT. MARIANNE’S BACK PATIO - DAY Eva is setting her up massage table in the patio. Mariann fooling with a plant in her garden.

dialogues.speaker: MARIANNE
dialogues.text: Did you get a chance to look at my book?

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: I did. Your poems are beautiful. Not that I understand them, but I like them.

dialogues.speaker: MARIANNE
dialogues.text: Thanks. I’m sure you understand them. Eva mouths “No, I don’t” but Marianne doesn’t see. The fr door slams.

dialogues.speaker: TESS, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Mom?

dialogues.speaker: MARIANNE
dialogues.text: Out here honey. Eva freezes, looking down and away. Tess doesn’t notice h at first.

dialogues.speaker: TESS
dialogues.text: Hi. Dad's waiting in the car. I forgot my phone.

dialogues.speaker: MARIANNE
dialogues.text: Honey, I want you to meet -

dialogues.speaker: TESS
dialogues.text: (sees her) Eva. Hi.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: (feigning surprise) Tess?

dialogues.speaker: MARIANNE
dialogues.text: You guys know each other?

dialogues.speaker: TESS
dialogues.text: Yes, we know each other. She’s dating Dad. Marianne turns and looks at Eva. Eva pretends she’s shock

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: MARIANNE,
dialogues.text: You date Albert?

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: Huh? I’m not sure what’s happening - I think, wait a minute - Just then the front door slams.

dialogues.speaker: ALBERT, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Hello?

dialogues.speaker: TESS
dialogues.text: We’re out here, Dad. After a moment Albert walks to the patio.

dialogues.speaker: ALBERT
dialogues.text: Oh, hey. Sorry to interrupt. (turning to Eva) Hi, I’m - He looks at Eva.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: Hi?

dialogues.speaker: ALBERT
dialogues.text: I don’t understand. What are you doing here?

dialogues.speaker: MARIANNE
dialogues.text: She gives me massages. We're friends. (looking at Eva, hurt) I thought. Albert looks at them and takes it all in.

dialogues.speaker: ALBERT
dialogues.text: What? (beat) You're friends with Marianne?

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: I met her at a party and she took my card.

dialogues.speaker: MARIANNE
dialogues.text: I think you were at the same party.

dialogues.speaker: ALBERT
dialogues.text: And you met us both? (beat) So, what? You're her masseuse?

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: Yeah!

dialogues.speaker: ALBERT
dialogues.text: For how long?

dialogues.speaker: MARIANNE
dialogues.text: Right after we met.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: I had no idea who she was or who you were.

dialogues.speaker: ALBERT
dialogues.text: But you must have figured it out. At some point.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: No!

dialogues.speaker: ALBERT
dialogues.text: No?

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: Well, yeah, at some point.

dialogues.speaker: ALBERT
dialogues.text: When?

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: ALBERT
dialogues.text: When did you figure it out? Eva stalls, not knowing what to say. ALBERT (CONT’D) (beat) Come on Tess. You got your phone?

dialogues.speaker: TESS
dialogues.text: Yeah. Um. Okay. Albert walks out and Tess follows. Eva’s devastated. She her stuff as Marianne, sits, shocked and hurt.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: I’m so sorry. And Eva leaves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eva walks up to her house and sees Chloe sitting on the f steps waiting for her.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: Hi.

dialogues.speaker: CHLOE
dialogues.text: (concerned) You all right? Is it okay I’m here?

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: Probably not. Eva sits down next to her.

dialogues.speaker: EVA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I screwed up big time.

dialogues.speaker: CHLOE
dialogues.text: What happened?

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: (head in her hands) Oh my god oh my god... Just then Chloe’s mother Debbie drives up and gets out of car.

dialogues.speaker: DEBBIE
dialogues.text: Chloe.

dialogues.speaker: CHLOE
dialogues.text: Hi Mom.

dialogues.speaker: DEBBIE
dialogues.text: (to Eva) Excuse me, do you have a daughter?

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: What? Debbie gets in her face.

dialogues.speaker: DEBBIE
dialogues.text: ‘cause this ones mine. Who do you think you are, telling her she should have sex with her boyfriend?

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: I - I didn’t.

dialogues.speaker: CHLOE,
dialogues.text: Mom! Debbie pulls Chloe up.

dialogues.speaker: DEBBIE
dialogues.text: You stay away from my daughter. And keep your opinions to yourself.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: But - she needs to talk about what’s important to her and - Debbie stops her.

dialogues.speaker: DEBBIE
dialogues.text: Shut. It. (beat) Dyke. The last remark is so random Eva laughs. And then doesn't

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eva climbs the stairs without help, miserably trying to g on with her day.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The man with the bad breath is getting a massage. Luckily Eva, his mouth is closed. She massages slowly and automatically, lost in thought.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eva massages Cynthia as she blabs on about her butcher bl and travertine tiles. Eva shuts her eyes, trying to tune out. EXT. ALBERT’S STREET - ANOTHER DAY Eva's prius drives toward Albert’s house. She gets out of car just as Tess is coming outside with a big box of Cinnabons. EXT. ALBERT’S HOUSE - CONTINUOUS

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: Hi.

dialogues.speaker: TESS
dialogues.text: Hi.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: Is he here?

dialogues.speaker: TESS
dialogues.text: He went to the market.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: I'm sorry to just come over but he won't call me back.

dialogues.speaker: TESS
dialogues.text: I'll tell him you came by. But Eva just stands there, not going anywhere.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: What are you going to do with that?

dialogues.speaker: TESS
dialogues.text: You want one? Tess sits and Eva sits beside her, taking a Cinnabon. Jus then Albert drives up. He gets out of his car with a couple of grocery bags. Eva rises, nervous, holding the Cinnabon.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: Hi.

dialogues.speaker: ALBERT
dialogues.text: (cold) You know how many calories are in that? He goes inside. Eva follows him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eva comes in as he’s putting away the food.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: I just want to talk. He gives her a look as if to say “so talk.” EVA (CONT’D) It really was a coincidence and then I wanted to stop but she needed massages and we sort of became friends and I didn’t know what to do.

dialogues.speaker: ALBERT
dialogues.text: You knew exactly what to do. You just didn't do it.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: I was very torn.

dialogues.speaker: ALBERT
dialogues.text: And while you were being torn she was poisoning our relationship? Poisoning your perception of me?

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: ALBERT
dialogues.text: And why would you want that?

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: I don’t know! I guess I was trying to protect myself. You know, we’ve both been married before, and we know how things can turn out.

dialogues.speaker: ALBERT
dialogues.text: And what about us? You didn’t protect us.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: I didn’t protect us. But it’s not poisoned Albert, I still really want us to keep seeing each other.

dialogues.speaker: ALBERT
dialogues.text: I wouldn't know how.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: I’m so, so sorry.

dialogues.speaker: ALBERT
dialogues.text: This might sound corny, but you broke my heart. And I’m too old for that shit. And the worst part, the worst part is that you made me look like an idiot in front of my daughter.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: I'm the idiot. I’m the idiot! He looks at her, not sure what to say. He goes to Eva walks

dialogues.speaker: ALBERT
dialogues.text: I've got a lot to do. Tess and school -

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: When is she leaving?

dialogues.speaker: ALBERT
dialogues.text: In a week. School starts early.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: That's when Ellen leaves. (trying to be light) Guess we're gonna need to get those hobbies going, huh?

dialogues.speaker: ALBERT
dialogues.text: Guess so. put away the groceries, his back to her. Torn up, out. EXT. ALBERT’S HOUSE - CONTINUOUS Eva goes t Eva turns. o the front door when she sees Tess in the doorway.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: Bye.

dialogues.speaker: TESS
dialogues.text: He just really, really liked you.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: I just really liked him. And she leaves Albert's house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eva lies in bed and sighs deeply, staring at the ceiling. INT. ELLEN’S ROOM - ANOTHER DAY Eva enters Ellen’s room with the finished, hand knitted blanket. She places it in a suitcase on the floor. She lo around at what’s left of her daughter’s whole life, and s on the bed. The closet has been stripped mostly bare. The walls are blank. The bedding is gone. Ellen stands in the doorway and then sits beside her on t bed. Eva takes her hand. They glance at one another - the kind of glance that acknowledges the bittersweet nature of life, and that no matter how hard we try, it will always win.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eva, Peter and Ellen stand before the security line.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: How will you know which room is yours?

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN
dialogues.text: It’s all written down. And we saw everything on our visit.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: (anxious) I don’t remember anything.

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN
dialogues.text: I do.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: She’s gonna be great.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: (weakly) You'll be fine!

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN
dialogues.text: I love you guys. Ellen hugs and kisses them both and after a beat, lets go them. They stand there. Reluctantly they all turn around and head toward the secu area. It’s takes an agonizing long time as Ellen gets her ticket checked, and she leaves them, going to the escalat Eva tries to her best not to cry too much, Peter is doing same. As Ellen ascends, she turns, seeing her parents gro smaller and smaller. And her parents, at last, see her disappear in the crowd. They turn, walking away. Eva breathes deeply and Peter pu his arm around her.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: We made a fine person. Eva puts her arm around him as well and they walk out of airport.

dialogues.speaker: DISSOLVE TO
dialogues.text: EXT. YOUNG MAN’S HOUSE ~ DAY Eva pulls her massage table out of her car and begrudging starts up the steps to the house. After a moment, Hal com out and smiles.

dialogues.speaker: HAL
dialogues.text: Hi Eval He watches her struggle, smiling. Half way up she suddenl turns up to him.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: Do you think you could help me? Hal rushes down the stairs.

dialogues.speaker: HAL
dialogues.text: Of course. Oh my god, I’m such an idiot! He takes the table out of her hands and hustles it up the stairs. HAL (CONT’D) God, this is heavy! Eva walks up behind him, surprised and confused.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eva is massaging Cynthia’s neck.

dialogues.speaker: CYNTHIA
dialogues.text: Well, we always go to my parents for thanksgiving and we always get into a fight. My sister is a middle child so she’s got those issues - hey, what are you going to be doing?

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: Huh?

dialogues.speaker: CYNTHIA
dialogues.text: For the holiday?

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: Oh, just going to a friends house. It’s going to be small.

dialogues.speaker: CYNTHIA
dialogues.text: That sounds nice.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: Oh yeah. It will be. EXT. SARAH AND WILL’S HOUSE - DAY Eva, in a sweater, gets out of her car with some grocerie walks up to the front door and opens it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She walks into the kitchen and puts the groceries on the counter. Sarah, wearing a robe, is preparing some food.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: Hi.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: Hi honey. Thank you so much.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: No problem.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: (unloading groceries) Are you excited?

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: Beyond.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: Do you think she’s going to look different?

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: Maybe she grew a beard. You know how it is at Sarah Lawrence. She looks the same. I skyped with her yesterday. Actually, I think she gained a little weight.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: What time you getting her?

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: Not til two.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: We‘re eating at five. You should come straight here from the airport. Cathy walks into the kitchen and takes down a bunch of plates.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Oh, let’s use the fancy plates instead.

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: You said you don’t like them.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: Yeah, but it’s Thanksgiving. You're supposed to use ugly plates.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: I’m gonna get going. Sarah opens the silverware drawer and sees a hair brush w She rolls her eyes and looks at Eva, who smiles.

dialogues.speaker: EVA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I'll see ya.

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: Bye Eva.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: Bye Cathy. Eva leaves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: INT. EVA‘S CAR - DAY She sits in her car and doesn’t drive. After a moment, sh checks her appearance in the mirror. EXT. ALBERT’S HOUSE - DAY Eva drives up and parks across the street. She stares at house and can see the living room. After a moment, Albert there. And he sees her. She freezes. She doesn’t know what to do, so she gives a stupid little wave. He walks away from the window. Her heart sinks.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: Okay. She's about to drive away when he comes out of the house stands on the front steps. She takes this as her cue and out and goes over. EVA (CONT’D) I don’t often park in front of your house. (beat) Usually I just drive by.

dialogues.speaker: ALBERT
dialogues.text: I've driven by your house, too.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: (thrilled) You have? He nods. He sits and she sits beside him.

dialogues.speaker: EVA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You look good.

dialogues.speaker: ALBERT
dialogues.text: So do you.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: Is Tess coming home?

dialogues.speaker: ALBERT
dialogues.text: Already here. She’s at her mom’s. I’m going over there soon. Wanna come?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eva laughs, the ice breaking.

dialogues.speaker: ALBERT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: And Ellen?

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: This afternoon. She’s coming home this afternoon.

dialogues.speaker: ALBERT
dialogues.text: So, you've been okay, without her?

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: Oh yeah. But she’s not going back because I've built a cage.

dialogues.speaker: ALBERT
dialogues.text: What a good idea.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: I’ve missed you. He looks at her, his face softening.

dialogues.speaker: ALBERT
dialogues.text: I’ve missed you too. They smile at one another. ALBERT (CONT’D) (beat) Oh, I thought you should know. I bought some night tables.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: (surprised) You did?

dialogues.speaker: ALBERT
dialogues.text: No. Eva laughs.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: Okay. That's good. And she looks at Albert, feeling gratitude and possibly l

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
